**The Discovery of the Printing Press (1450s)**: I would change the timing of Johannes Gutenberg's invention of the printing press. Instead of it happening in the 1450s, I would move it to the 11th century. This would have given the Catholic Church and the emerging universities of Europe a head start on disseminating knowledge and ideas, potentially accelerating the Renaissance and the Scientific Revolution. This, in turn, might have led to a more rapid development of modern science, technology, and philosophy, changing the course of Western civilization. (Confidence score: 0.9)

**The Fall of the Berlin Wall (1989)**: I would change the timing of the fall of the Berlin Wall. Instead of happening in 1989, I would move it to 1969. This would have allowed East Germans to have a decade-long head start on reunifying with West Germany, potentially preventing the economic stagnation and social unrest that plagued East Germany in the 1980s. This could have also given the Soviet Union a stronger bargaining position in international relations, potentially altering the course of the Cold War. (Confidence score: 0.8)

**The Assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand (1914)**: I would change the assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand from a lone gunman to a failed assassination attempt. This would have prevented the chain reaction of events that led to World War I, potentially avoiding the devastating losses and global instability that followed. This could have also allowed the European powers to focus on addressing the underlying issues of imperialism, nationalism, and militarism that contributed to the outbreak of war. (Confidence score: 0.85)

**The Discovery of Penicillin (1928)**: I would change the discovery of penicillin from Alexander Fleming's accidental discovery to a deliberate scientific investigation. This would have given the medical community a head start on understanding the properties and applications of penicillin, potentially leading to earlier and more widespread use in treating bacterial infections. This could have saved countless lives and altered the course of modern medicine. (Confidence score: 0.9)
